Package edu.cornell.gdiac.audio

Interface AudioEngine

All Superinterfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.Audio
public interface AudioEngine extends com.badlogic.gdx.Audio
This interface provides an audio controller with more functionality than Audio. In particular, this interface allows the user to create AudioSource objects that are not explicitly attached to a Sound or Music asset. It also provides explicit access to the SoundEffect and MusicQueue interfaces. As with Audio{, all All resources created via this interface have to be disposed as soon as they are no longer used. Despite what Audio claims, no sound instances (not even Music) are paused when the application is minimized (it was not clear that this was respected in all instances of class Audio). It is your responsibility to pause() the engine from the appropriate ApplicationListener.

    newAudioDevice, newAudioRecorder

  • Method Details

    • getCapacity

      int getCapacity()
      Returns the number of simultaneous sound sources supported by this audio engine. Possible simultaneous sound sources include instances of SoundEffect, MusicQueue, and AudioDevice.

    • newSource

      AudioSource newSource(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file)
      Creates a new {#link AudioSource} from the given file. A sample is a music asset that is not explicitly associated with the audio engine. You can read data directly and pass it to an AudioDevice. Alternatively, you can queue the sample on to a MusicQueue to support gapless transitions in your music. The currently supported formats are WAV, MP3 and OGG. The audio source should be disposed if it is no longer used via the Disposable.dispose() method.
      Parameters:
      file - The sound asset
      Returns:
      a new {#link Sample} from the given file.
      Throws:
      com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException - if the asset could not be loaded

    • newSound

      SoundEffect newSound(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file)
      Creates a new SoundEffect which to play back audio effects. Sound buffers should be used for low latency effects such as gun shots or explosions. The audio data is retrieved from the file specified and loaded fully into memory. While there is no upper limit on the audio file size, you should avoid using this method for any sound asset greater than 1 MB. The currently supported formats are WAV, MP3 and OGG. The sound buffer should be disposed if it is no longer used via the Sound.dispose() method.
      Specified by:
      newSound in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Audio
      Parameters:
      file - The sound asset
      Returns:
      a new {#link SoundBuffer} from the given file.
      Throws:
      com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException - if the asset could not be loaded

    • newSoundBuffer

      SoundEffect newSoundBuffer(AudioSource source)
      Creates a new SoundEffect which to play back audio effects. Sound buffers should be used for low latency effects such as gun shots or explosions. The audio data is retrieved from the file specified and loaded fully into memory. While there is no upper limit on the audio file size, you should avoid using this method for any sound asset greater than 1 MB. The currently supported formats are WAV, MP3 and OGG. The sound buffer should be disposed if it is no longer used via the Sound.dispose() method.
      Parameters:
      source - The sound asset
      Returns:
      a new {#link SoundBuffer} from the given audio source.

    • newMusic

      MusicQueue newMusic(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file)
      Creates a new MusicQueue to stream from the given file. A music buffer streams music from the sound asset without fully loading it into memory. This is idea for long running music. The currently supported formats are WAV, MP3 and OGG. It is possible to append additional AudioSource instances to a music buffer. Doing so creates gapless playback from one music track to another. All sources added to this buffer must have the same sample rate and audio channels (mono or stereo) as the original. Despite what Audio claims, no sound instances (not even Music) are paused when the application is minimized (it was not clear that this was respected in all instances of class Audio). It is your responsibility to pause() the engine from the appropriate ApplicationListener.
      Specified by:
      newMusic in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Audio
      Parameters:
      file - The sound asset
      Returns:
      a new {#link MusicBuffer} from the given file.
      Throws:
      com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException - if the asset could not be loaded

    • newMusicBuffer

      MusicQueue newMusicBuffer(boolean isMono, int sampleRate)
      Creates a new MusicQueue with the given properties. A music buffer streams music from the sound asset without fully loading it into memory. This is idea for long running music. The currently supported formats are WAV, MP3 and OGG. This music asset starts out with no contents and so playing it will not produce any sound. To create music, you should append additional AudioSource instances to a music buffer. Doing so creates gapless playback from one music track to another. All sources added to this buffer must have the same sample rate and audio channels (mono or stereo) as this buffer. Despite what Audio claims, no sound instances (not even Music) are paused when the application is minimized (it was not clear that this was respected in all instances of class Audio). It is your responsibility to pause() the engine from the appropriate ApplicationListener.
      Parameters:
      isMono - Whether this is a mono stream (as opposed to stereo)
      sampleRate - The fixed sample rate of this stream
      Returns:
      a new {#link MusicBuffer} with the given properties.

    • pause

      void pause()
      Pauses all sound instances associated with this audio engine. This will pause everything, and not just music. This is the method that should be called when your application is minimized.

    • resume

      void resume()
      Pauses all sound instances previously paused. This will only resume sound instances that were paused by the global pause() method. Sound instances paused via their own local pause interface will not be affected.

    • getEffectFactory

      EffectFactory getEffectFactory()
      Gets the EffectFactory for creating EffectFilter
      Returns:
      EffectFactory class for generating sound filters
